description.narrative: BIOREVIEW is a biorefining collaboration between industry and academics in UK and India that aims to develop novel industrial biotechnology (IB) processes to produce value added products from waste streams of the Indian sugar industry. The pilot scale (TRL 4-6) IB solutions will process sugar cane bagasse (SCB) and spent wash (SW) at sufficient quantities to demonstrate viable economic opportunities and waste management options through the development of a bio-product portfolio. This involves demonstrating bio-production of higher value volatile fatty acids (VFAs), xylitol and microcrystalline cellulose (MCC) for the agri, food and pharmaceutical sectors. The scalable IB procedures offer improved environmental sustainability options over conventional manufacture and use membrane technology to increase the product value alongside a novel high productivity IB process for xylitol production from SCB. Delivery of a validated integrated biorefining process design evaluated for its economic, social and environmental benefits will inform diversification strategies and investment plans of the Indian sugarcane industry for commercial production of these commodities from waste streams.

Objectives: Building on the research base of UK-Indian academics and the commercial expertise of MAN, FE, MEM, LCAW and GSL, BIOREVIEW will demonstrate at pilot-scale (TRL 4-6): 1) a self-powered continuous biorefining unit (CBU) capable of processing SW to VFA at a rate of 1.5 m3/day. The CBU will be installed and validated at GSL-K to produce 30-40 kg/day of VFAs alongside nutrient recovery. VFA performance will be continuously validated for 6-12 months operation, converting >225 m3 of SW effluent into clean water, VFA (6.75-9 t) and nutrient (0.75 t; >£1k/t); 2) Xylooligosaccharide (XOS) extraction from up to 4 dry t SCB. AU's xylitol biorefining process (XBP) yeast strain will be further improved to convert XOS to xylitol and improve productivity from 1.33 to 2.2 kg m3 h-1 (250 L max). The XBP currently achieves maximum bioconversion to xylitol (1:1) at the fastest rate reported at 150 L using crude wheat straw hydrolysate (patent filing ref:1713622.7). 3) SCB fibre activation with VFAs to produce water filtration systems by adapting BU patent GB2398518A and generate added value by addressing other challenge areas in processing industrial water effluent; 4) determine the economic potential of extracting high value MCC from SCB in the range of 259 kg/dry t. Simultaneous to the aforementioned technical, economic and environmental validation a post project scale-up and implementation plan will be prepared. Meeting these objectives will ensure that within two years of the completion of this project the consortium will secure commercial funding for an industrial scale CBU (19 m3/h) and a bagasse to xylitol platform (1 t/h) to be operational at GSL-K. In addition, during the 3 year project duration over four technical advances will be enabled to not only improve waste recovery at GSL-K but also provide consultation to implement FE's hi-solid AD process within existing operations.Within the 3 year duration and combined India-UK funding (£2.2M requested; £2.65M eligible) BIOREVIEW will deliver a validated, pilot scale integrated biorefining process design to inform investment plans of GSL and other Indian sugar mill owners for diversification and commercial production of these commodities from current waste streams.
